ratings.comment: Gandhi is one of the easier Econ 101 professors.  However, he is not very good at public speaking and seems to talk in circles around a simple point.  Test was easier because questions were taken directly from lecture.

Gandhi was a nice enough guy and his test wasn't too difficult, but he was nearly impossible to follow during lectures. He seemed incredibly scatterbrained at times and rarely even acknowledges that he has a class. Luckily, he only taught half of the semester.
Overall a good teacher who knows well the material. Slides were very funny.

gandhi provided decent review of concepts during class, but did not effectively introduce them. for first timers of econ, you absolutely have to read the book! if you do, you'll understand most of what you need to know, and the rest comes from the previous exams that he posts online. other than that, don't expect to learn much from gandhi!

Gandhi definitely wasn't the greatest at teaching the material effectively. Compared to Serrano (who taught the other half of the course) he was very confusing. Did a lot of examples and talked a lot without explaining what we're supposed to learn from the lecture. Tests were not similar to examples covered in lecture. Not horrible, but not great.

Class is hard to follow because it's pretty boring.  Test questions don't relate well to the material that is covered in class or the homework.  He focuses too much on specifics instead of general ideas and concepts of the course of economics.
A pretty mundane class with an average professor.

I did not like the way Professor Gandhi taught. His homework and test questions were way too wordy and confusing. I had to reread every question and just confused myself. He made simple econ concepts harder than necessary. It was hard to learn in class. I got much more learning done in my TA section.

This class really got me into economics.  Gandhi is a great lecturer - his slides are fun, and easily to follow.  But most of all, he's a great speaker - he wants you to know this material, and puts it all in a context that you can understand.  The class is very easy, as long as you can apply basic logic and simple math to the concepts presented.

He was a really hard professor, homework was from the book but some questions were hard to understand. Tests were touch and if you dont get a good T.A. then you are screwed!! Make sure you get one that speaks english! He mostly structured his lectures around examples and never told you the actual definition. Good luck if you take econ with him!

Gandi is a great professor! His lectures sometimes got long (I would advise printing out the lectures before going to class because sometimes he goes quick) - the tests aren't awful but the curve can be tough.  Make sure to study for the final because it cane make/break your grade. Also, do well on homework because it helps more than you think!
It was a very boring class...homework was straight from the book examples so it was easy to figure out.  I just don't care for Econ -- he was pleasant to look at though!

Gandhi is a good lecturer, but I've found he emphasizes things which aren't tested heavily on the exams. However he does help to clarify complicated economic theory. If you are bad at math, don't expect to get any help from lectures. And if you were like me and have a bad TA, you will have a lot of problems with the math. Overall, good prof though.
He is amazing! I really like his style of teaching, making things so interesting and clear. Definitely choose him as your eco 101 professor!

I found his lectures mostly irrelevant.  The homework was all online and he posted the powerpoints online, too, so I just read the book and did all the homework on my own time.  The exams were pretty easy.
Gandhi is a good prof.  Lecture can be slow but the class is not too hard and the homework is pretty easy and helpful.  I would definitely recommend him, but the powerlecture might be kind of boring.
very nice guy, the power lecture could get a little long, but he always posted powerpoints online which was great, pretty much said everyone was getting a B
